item.title: 01: GODDESSES IN VEDIC LITERATURE
item.description: Sometimes the idea of śruti is narrowed to mean primarily the Upaniṣads. The idea of śruti often also includes the Bhāgavad-gītā, which is much later than most Vedic literature. For example, Sukumari Bhattacharji, The Indian Theogony (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1970), pp. 160–161; Stella Kramrisch, “The Indian Great Goddess,” History of Religions 14, no. 4 (May 1975): 235–265. For example, Śatapatha-brāhmaṇa 2.2.1.19; 3.2.3.6, 19; 4.5.1.2; Aitareya-brāhmaṇa 1.8. For example, Śatapatha-brāhmaṇa 14.

item.title: 02: ŚRĪ-LAKṢMĪ
item.description: Throughout this chapter I have assumed that Śrī and Lakṣmī are the same. It seems clear that in almost every case the names refer to the same goddess. For a discussion of the evidence suggesting their independent identity, see Bandana Saraswati, “The History of the Worship of Srī in North India to cir. A.D. 550” (Ph.D. diss., University of London, 1971), pp. 291-296. Jan Gonda, Aspects of Early Viṣṇuism, 2d ed.

item.title: 03: PARVATĪ
item.description: Vājasaneyī-saṁhitā 3.57. Taittīriya-brāhmāṇa 1.6.10.4-5. For example, Śiva-purāṇa, Vāyavīya-saṁhitā 2.2.46-60. M. C. P. Srivastava, Mother Goddess in Indian Art, Archaeology and Literature (Delhi: Agam Kala Prakashan, 1979), p. 81. The following account of the myth of Satī primarily follows the Śiva-purāṇa’s account of the story. For example, Kālikā-purāṇa 2-4. See my chapter 12, “Goddesses and Sacred Geography.” Kāmarūpa is one of the most famous centers of goddess worship in India today.

item.title: 07: DURGĀ
item.description: Taittirīya-āranyaka 10.1.7. M. C. P. Srivastava, Mother Goddess in Indian Art, Archaeology and Literature (Delhi: Agam Kala Prakashan, 1979), pp. 111-113; Jitendra Nath Banerjea, The Development of Hindu Iconography, 2d ed. (Calcutta: University of Calcutta, 1956), pp. 495-500. The most celebrated text describing Durgā’s mythological exploits is the Devī-māhātmya, which constitutes chapters 81-93 of the Mārkandeya-purāṇa. The myth of Durgā defeating Mahiṣa is also found in the Vāmana-purāṇa 19.1-21.52; Varāha-purāṇa 62.

item.title: 09: THE MAHĀDEVĪ
item.description: Some scholars have assumed that an underlying goddess theology asserting the essential unity of all goddesses has existed in Hinduism since the Vedic period. See, for example, Stella Kramrisch, “The Indian Great Goddess,” History of Religions 14, no. 4 (May 1975): 235-265; J. Przyluski, “The Great Goddess of India and Iran,” Indian Historical Quarterly 10 (1934): 405-430; and Sadanand K. Dikshit, The Mother Goddess (New Delhi: Published by the author, 1957).

item.title: 11: TĀRĀ, CHINNAMASTĀ, AND THE MAHĀVIDYĀS
item.description: See my chapter 9, “The Mahādevī.” For example, Vāmana-purāṇa 30.3-9. For example, Devī-māhātmya 11.38-50. D. C. Sircar, The Śākta Pīṭhas (Delhi: Motilal Banarsidass, 1973), p. 48. David Kinsley, “The Portrait of the Goddess in the Devī-māhātmya,” Journal of the American Academy of Religion 46, no. 4 (December 1978): 498. Mahābhāgavata-purāṇa 8.50-52. Ibid. 8.57-71. The list of ten Mahāvidyās is the same in the Bṛhaddharma-purāṇa, except that the goddesses are given in a different order (Madhya-khaṇḍa 6).

item.title: 12: GODDESSES AND SACRED GEOGRAPHY
item.description: See the section on Pṛthivī in my chapter 1. An even earlier example of this idea is found in Ṛg-veda 10.90, where the creation of the world is described as the result of the sacrifice of a giant being who is dismembered. The parts of the world are composed of the parts of his body. Wendy O’Flaherty, Asceticism and Eroticism in the Mythology of Śiva (London: Oxford University Press, 1973), passim, has shown that a similar idea underlies much of śaivite mythology.
